text:
All of our JSPS include the following Meta TAG:

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=UTF-8">

When we load our jsp page in Explorer 5.0 and above using Netscape IPLANET, our 
German characters, pulled from a database and placed in an object for retrieval 
on the jsp page, are correctly displayed. 

However in Explorer 5.0 and above using Tomcat, our German characters that are 
pulled from a database and placed in an object for retrieval on the jsp page, 
are displayed as boxes and junk. I did a view source, and the correct 
characters are in the source of the page, but are not displayed properly in the 
browser when we use Tomcat.

Is there a configuration file that we need to set up so that the Tomcat server 
will convert the meta tag into an http header?

The really strange this is that this just "stopped" working when using Tomcat. 
We don't know of any changes we may have made to the Tomcat configuration.
creator: nclayton@acumensolutions.com
Larry.Isaacs@sas.com
text:
I assume the answer has been discovered by now. To document it here, JSP
supports setting the "content-type" using:

    <%@ page contentType="text/html; charset=UTF-8" %>

JSP will include a default content-type of "text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1" if
not specified otherwise.  I'm not sure what the expected result would be with
the default content-type and the META tag.
